definition[0]: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
note[0]: keep left/right (=stay to the left or right of a path or road as you move)
example[0]: You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.
example[1]: Peter cycles to work to keep fit.
example[2]: Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!
example[3]: How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!
example[4]: We huddled around the fire to keep warm.
example[5]: I was struggling to keep awake.
example[7]: some toys to keep the kids amused
example[8]: The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.
example[9]: If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.
example[11]: The little boy kept close to his mother.
example[13]: You keep out of this, Mother  (=do not get involved). It’s no concern of yours.
explanation[0]: Keep is used as a linking verb in this meaning It links the subject of the sentence with an adjective
example[16]: The fruit will keep fresh for several weeks
definition[1]: to continue doing something or to do the same thing many times
example[17]: I keep thinking about Joe, all alone in that place.
example[18]: I keep telling you, but you won’t listen!
example[19]: She pretended not to hear, and kept on walking.
explanation[1]: Keep is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You say
bad_example[0]: He kept to talk to me
definition[2]: to have something and not give it back to the person who had it before
example[21]: You can keep it. I don’t need it anymore.
definition[3]: to continue to have something and not lose it or get rid of it
example[22]: We decided to keep our old car instead of selling it.
example[23]: I kept his letters for years.
example[24]: In spite of everything, Robyn’s managed to keep her sense of humor.
definition[4]: to leave something in one particular place so that you can find it easily
example[25]: Where do you keep your teabags?
example[26]: George kept a bottle of whiskey under his bed.
signpost[5]: make somebody stay in a place
definition[5]: to make someone stay in a place, especially a prison or hospital
example[27]: He was kept in prison for a week without charge.
example[28]: He should be here by now. What’s keeping him?
definition[7]: to do what you have promised or agreed to do
example[29]: patients who fail to keep their appointments
example[30]: How do I know you’ll keep your word?
definition[8]: if food keeps, it stays fresh enough to be eaten
example[31]: Eat the salmon because it won’t keep till tomorrow.
definition[9]: to own and look after animals
example[32]: We keep chickens and a couple of pigs.
signpost[8]: stop other people from using something
definition[10]: to stop other people from using something, so that it is available for someone
example[33]: Will you keep a seat for me?
definition[11]: to own a small business and work in it
definition[12]: to provide someone with money, food etc
example[34]: He did not earn enough to keep a wife and children.
example[35]: There’s enough money there to keep you in champagne for a year!
example[36]: The Lord bless you and keep you.
example[37]: His only thought was to keep the child from harm.
example[38]: Where do you keep the scissors?
example[39]: The keys are kept in my office.
definition[14]: to put things away and keep them until you need them
example[40]: Villagers have begun storing wood for the winter.
definition[15]: to keep something so that you can use or enjoy it in the future
example[41]: He had been saving the bottle of champagne for a special occasion.
example[42]: We can save the rest of the pie for later.
definition[16]: to store papers or information in a particular order or a particular place
example[43]: All the contracts are filed alphabetically.
definition[17]: to get and keep objects of the same type because you think they are attractive or interesting
definition[18]: to keep something to be used when it is needed, especially something that many different people may need to use
example[45]: Medical records are now usually held on computers.
definition[19]: to keep part of something for use at a later time during a process such as cooking
example[46]: Reserve some of the chocolate so that you can use it for decorating the cake.
definition[20]: to keep large amounts of food, money etc because you think you may not be able to get them in the future – used when you do not approve of people doing this because it is not necessary or not fair to other people
example[47]: People have been hoarding food and fuel in case there is another attack.
example[48]: Rationing of basic food products was introduced to prevent hoarding.
definition[21]: a large strong tower, usually in the centre of a castle
definition[22]: to store something that will be useful
example[49]: The Credit Reference Agency keeps files on individuals’ debt records.
example[50]: You shouldkeep a supply of forms.
definition[23]: to regularly record written information somewhere
